page.title: 18Landscape of Yewdale 1
page.content: {Traditional Lakeland architecture forms the basis for the dwellings in our block, with rendered slatestone, slate roofs, massive chimney stacks, small windows and sometimes slate slab porches. These are found in sheltered situations, usually south-facing and above flood level. The associated agricultural buildings often contain two storeys and occasionally a {"spinning gallery",}which is thought to have been used as an open-sided workspace in the days of the cottage textile industry.{Yew Tree Farm (319998) is a well known example. The row of cottages at{Far End (303982), in the same local materials, was originally built for miners and quarrymen. Significantly, there are no modern-style buildings in the block, showing the control exerted by the {Planning Board}and the{National Trust.
